column1: Google Street View is a technology featured in Google Maps and Google Earth that provides interactive panoramas from positions along many streets in the world. It was launched in 2007 in several cities in the United States
column2: and has since expanded to include cities and rural areas worldwide. Streets with Street View imagery available are shown as blue lines on Google Maps.

column1: Google Street View displays panoramas of stitched images. Most photography is done by car
column2: but some is done by tricycle
column3: boat

column1: == History and features ==
Street View had its inception in 2001 with the Stanford CityBlock Project
column2: a Google-sponsored Stanford University research project. The project ended in June 2006
column3: and its technology was folded into StreetView.

column1: 2007: Launched on May 25 in the United States using Immersive Media technology.

2008: In May Google announces that it was testing face-blurring technology on its photos of the busy streets of Manhattan. The technology uses a computer algorithm to search Google's image database for faces and blurs them. Street View was integrated into Google Earth 4.3
column2: the Maps application on the Apple iPhone
column3: and the Maps application for S60 3rd Edition. In November
column4: the drag and drop Pegman icon is introduced as the primary user interface element for connecting from Maps' 2D view into Street View's 3D view. When Pegman is dropped onto a particular set of coordinates in Google Maps for which Street View data is available
column5: Street View opens and takes over the whole map window.

column1: 2009: Introduction of a full-screen option. Smart Navigation was introduced allowing users to navigate around the panoramas by double-clicking with their cursor on any place or object they want to see.
May 2011: Indoor views of businesses (Google Business Photos) were announced. After the pilot phase of several months
column2: the project was rolled out in earnest in autumn.

column1: November 2012: With the release of Android 4.2
column2: Google invites users to contribute panoramas of their own using supported devices. Google highlights user-contributed panoramas with blue circle icons on Maps. The company also created a website to highlight places in the world where one can find them.

column1: 2013: Business interior views are shown as small orange circles. Businesses such as shops
column2: cafés and other premises can pay a photographer to take panoramic images of the interior of their premises which are then included in Street View. Google sets up a program to let third parties borrow the Street View Trekker (a backpack-mounted camera) and contribute imagery to Google Maps.

column1: 2014: Street-level imagery from the past can now be seen
column2: if available for a given street view.

column1: 2015: A partnership was announced between Street View and the environmental monitoring company Aclima. Cars began carrying sensors to detect pollutants
column2: such as nitrogen dioxide
column3: ozone
column5: support for Google Cardboard was announced
column6: allowing users to utilize Street View in 360-degree virtual reality.

column1: 2017: Imagery inside the International Space Station is added to Street View.
2017: Starting in August
column2: Google allows users to create their own Street View-like blue paths
column3: for the connected photospheres that are sufficiently close to one another.

column1: 2017: On September 5
column2: Google announced that they are improving the quality of the street view panoramic photo
column3: revamping its mapping vehicles with all-new high-resolution camera systems and artificial intelligence to capture even better imagery. The new Google cars have been seen in various American cities since March 2017
column4: as well as in Japan since August. The first images taken with the new generation of cameras were available online on September 13.

column1: October 2017: The makers of the Insta360 Pro announce the certification of the first "Street View auto ready" camera for US$3500; it uses six lenses for a 360º view and comes with Stitcher software. In addition to purchase
column2: the camera rig is also available to qualified entities as part of the Google loaner program
column3: with 50 cameras available to loan
column4: making possible Google Street View imagery coverage of more places that Google might not visit
column5: and to entities for whom a purchase is impractical or impossible.

column1: 2018: Google Japan now offers the street view from a dog's perspective.
August 2018: Street View covers two offshore gas-extraction platforms in the North Sea.
== Implementation ==
Street View is available as a component of Google Maps
column2: as a web application
column3: and as a mobile application for Android and iOS. Originally
column4: Google Maps used Adobe Flash for Street View. Google overhauled Google Maps in 2013. The newer version uses JavaScript extensively and provides a JavaScript application programming interface. At the time of their release
column5: the new Google Maps and Street View are measured slower than the old version in various setups. A user can switch to the old version of Google Maps
column6: which is especially useful when Google Maps is more sluggish than usual.The drag-and-drop Pegman icon is the primary user interface element used by Google to connect Maps to Street View. Its name comes from its resemblance to a clothespeg. When not in use
column7: Pegman sits atop the Google Maps zoom controls. Occasionally Pegman "dresses up" for special events or is joined by peg friends in Google Maps. When dragged into Street View near Area 51
column8: he becomes a flying saucer. When viewing older views
column9: the Pegman in the minimap changes to Doc Brown from Back to the Future.

column1: == Coverage ==

Google announced in May 2017 that it had captured more than 10 million miles (16 million kilometres) of Street View imagery across 83 countries. Maps also include panoramic views taken underwater such as in West Nusa Tenggara underwater coral
column2: in the Grand Canyon
column3: inside museums
column4: and Liwa Desert in United Arab Emirates which are viewed from camelback. In a ten-day trek with Apa Sherpa
column8: monasteries and schools.Google also added landmarks in Egypt
column13: and the Citadel of Qaitbay in the 9 September 2014 release.

column1: Many places still have limited or no coverage
column2: including:

column1: The Caribbean – except Barbados
column2: Puerto Rico
column3: partial coverage in the United States Virgin Islands

column1: Central America – except Guatemala and some landmarks in Costa Rica
French Guiana
column2: Guyana
column3: Paraguay
column4: Suriname and Venezuela in South America

column1: Africa – except Botswana
column2: Eswatini (Swaziland)
column3: Ghana
column11: Uganda and some city views in Madagascar

column1: Belarus
column2: Bosnia and Herzegovina
column3: Kosovo
column5: Moldova and much of Germany and Austria in Europe

column1: Asia – except Bangladesh
column2: Bhutan
column3: Cambodia

column1: The Middle East – except Israel
column2: Jordan
column3: Turkey and the United Arab Emirates

column1: The South Pacific – except American Samoa
column2: Australia
column3: Cook Islands (Rarotonga)
column7: Pitcairn Islands (Pitcairn and Henderson Island) and Kingdom of Tonga (Tongatapu).

column1: == Data capturing equipment ==
Cameras: Street View imagery has come from several generations of camera systems from Immersive Media [1]
column2: Point Grey Research (now FLIR Systems) [2] and developed in-house. The cameras contain no mechanical parts
column3: including the shutter
column4: instead using CMOS sensors and an electronic rolling shutter. Widely deployed versions are:

column1: R2: the earliest after Immersive Media
column2: photos were captured with a ring of eight 11-megapixel CCD sensors with commercial photographic wide-angle lenses
column3: cameras with the same specifications as those used for the Google Books project.

column1: Ladybug2 cameras (resolution 1024 x 768 pixels) by Point Grey Research.
R5: uses a ring of eight 5-megapixel CMOS cameras by Elphel with custom low-flare lenses
column2: plus a camera with fisheye lens on top to capture upper levels of buildings.

column1: R7: is the first completely in-house built camera
column2: it uses 15 of the same sensors and lenses as R5
column3: but no fisheye effect.

column1: 2017: uses 8 20MP cameras. Includes two facing left and right to read street signs and business names.
Positioning: recorded photographs must be associated with accurate positioning. This is done via a Global Positioning System
column2: wheel speed sensor
column3: and inertial navigation sensor data.

column1: Laser range scanners from Sick AG for the measuring of up to 50 meters 180° in the front of the vehicle. These are used for recording the actual dimensions of the space being photographed.
LIDAR scanners from Velodyne were added in the 2017 update. Mounted at 45° to capture 3D depth information
column2: and used for additional positional information.

column1: Air quality: In September 2018
column2: Google announced it would integrate air quality sensors from Aclima into its global fleet of Street View vehicles.

column1: Vehicles: data recording equipment is usually mounted on the roof of a car. A Trike (tricycle) was developed to record pedestrian routes including Stonehenge
column2: and other UNESCO World Heritage Sites. In 2010 a snowmobile-based system captured the 2010 Winter Olympics sites. Trolleys have been used to shoot the insides of museums
column3: and in Venice the narrow roads were photographed with backpack-mounted cameras
column4: and canals were photographed from boats.

column1: A portable backpack-mounted Google Trekker is used in outdoor terrain. For instance
column2: the six main paths up Snowdon were mapped by the Google Trekker in 2015.

column1: == Privacy concerns ==
Google Street View will blur houses for any user who makes a request
column2: in addition to the automatic blurring of faces and licence plates. Privacy advocates have objected to the Google Street View
column3: pointing to views found to show men leaving strip clubs
column6: and people engaging in activities visible from public property in which they do not wish to be seen publicly. Another concern is the height of the cameras
column7: and in at least two countries
column9: Google has had to lower the height of its cameras so as to not peer over fences and hedges. The service also allows users to flag inappropriate or sensitive imagery for Google to review and remove.Police Scotland received an apology for wasting police time in 2014 from a local business owner in Edinburgh who in 2012 had staged a fake murder for the Google camera car by lying in the road "while his colleague stood over him with a pickaxe handle". In May 2010
column10: it was revealed that Google had collected and stored payload data from unencrypted Wi-Fi connections as part of Street View.The concerns have led to Google not providing or suspending the service in countries around the world.

column1: Austria: Google Street View was banned in Austria
column2: because Google was found to collect Wi-Fi data without authorization in 2010. After the ban was lifted
column3: rules were set up for how Street View can operate legally in Austria. Google resumed collecting imagery in 2017. As of 2018 Google Street View is available in select areas of Austria.

column1: Australia: In 2010
column2: Google Street View ceased operations in Australia
column3: following months of investigations from Australian authorities. However
column5: with Google announcing plans to continue production on May 4
column6: 2011 and subsequently releasing updated Street View imagery for Australian towns and cities on July 27

column1: Germany: In 2011
column2: after having put online the pictures of the 20 largest cities
column3: Google stopped taking Street View images in Germany.  However
column5: Google's website shows numerous areas of Germany as being scheduled for coverage by Street View vehicles over the ensuing months.

column1: India: In 2011
column2: Google stopped taking street images in India
column3: after receiving a letter from police authorities in Bangalore.

column1: Canada: Street View cars were spotted as early as September 2007 in Montreal. However
column2: service for Canada was delayed while they attempted to settle with the Canadian government over its privacy laws. Privacy and town beauty concerns were dealt with and Street View is available in Montreal and other Canadian cities (as of 2016).

column1: == Third-party use of images ==
Fine-art photographers have selected images for use in their own work. Although the images may be pixelated
column2: the colours muddy
column3: and the perspective warped
column4: the photographs have been published in book form and exhibited in art galleries
column5: such as the work of Jon Rafman at the Saatchi Gallery
column6: London. In his personal appreciation of Street View material
column7: Rafman sees images which evoke the "gritty urban life" depicted in American street photography and the images commissioned by the Farm Security Administration. He also invokes the "decisive moment" esthetic of Henri Cartier-Bresson "as if I were a photojournalist responding instantaneously to an emerging event".Michael Wolf won an honourable mention in Daily Life in the 2011 World Press Photo competition for some of his work using Google Street View.Mishka Henner was short-listed for the 2013 Deutsche Börse Photography Prize in November 2012 for his series 'No Man's Land'
column8: which depicts sex workers at rural roadside locations.Swedish programmer Anton Wallén developed a game called GeoGuessr
column9: which places players into a Google Street View and has them guess its location.Canadian artist
column11: worked in conjunction with John M. Lynch between 2013-14 to insert the first staged tableaux into the Google Street View engine. Their efforts won them the Lumen Prize in 2016. Borda has continued independently to author in the Google Street View engine and in 2017 created the tableaux series
